texts.definition: Quests which are optional to a game's main quest structure.
markups: <style="Definition">Quests which are optional to a game's main quest structure.</style>
Games that are built around players solving quests can have several types of quests. Sidequests are the ones that are not part of a larger main quest but instead are optional.

<style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> are most commonly found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> since they usually have extensive worlds and storylines. Examples of such games include the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/S.T.A.L.K.E.R.%20series">S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series</link></style> is an example of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooter</link></style> using <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style>.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> are quite similar to designing <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> in general. However, <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> assumes the presence of <style="Link"><link="main-quests">Main Quests</link></style> since they would otherwise be ordinary <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>.

Although not part of the main series of <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> in a game, <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> can be linked together to provide their own <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hierarchy%20of%20Goals">Hierarchy of Goals</link></style> and they can be incompatible with each other by making their goals be <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style>. One such example is <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style> that can be used to progress story arcs of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> functionally differ from <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> by having <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> but also differ through often being integrated in the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> of a game. Even so, <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> may be considered an alternative to <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> can add significantly to the amount of active <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> in a game. For this reason, games using them often provide the information about them in <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style>, like <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, are narration patterns. They can specifically be used to offer depth or detail to the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> related to <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> without forcing players to have to ally themselves with them.

<style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> are <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> that allow the <style="Link"><link="main-quests">Main Quests</link></style> of games to be complemented with <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>. These can be <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> since they can provide <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> like other <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, and provide players with a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> on how much of the game to explore.

When games have <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> that are incompatible with each other, or have more <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> than can reasonably be completed in one game session, their existence supports <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> of the games.  <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style> that have <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> to each other allows players to perform <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> by choosing between these incompatible <style="CurrentLink">Sidequests</style>.

<style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style>
